liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A reminder that NSW's south coast and Greater Sydney regions are still under an extreme fire danger rating and a total fire ban. The maximum temperature is set to reach 35C in Bega and 33C in Sydney. Authorities in the alerted regions are warning residents to take action to protect life and property. Here's the Bega Valley Shire Mayor, Russell Fitzpatrick, talking about the widespread school closures today due to fire warnings.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bega mayor says NSW communities have 'high anxiety' around extreme bushfire danger

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There are concerns that an indexation increase for Australians on income support will do little to help with cost of living pressures. From tomorrow, the unemployment payment will rise from 50 dollars a day to 54, while youth allowance will increase from 40 dollars to 43. CEO of the Australian Council of Social Service, Cassandra Goldie, says JobSeeker is still just 39 per cent of the minimum wage and will remain a "povery payment". "On any measures, these increases are nowhere near what is needed to protect people on the very lowest incomes from the financial crisis they're facing," she says. "Of course, we know housing, rents have gone up dramatically, food, of course, and also those energy bills. So we continue to be very concerned." Goldie says even with tomorrow's boost, JobSeeker will still be the lowest unemployement payment among all of the OECD's 38 member countries.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian Council of Social service says JobSeeker increase still a 'poverty payment'

"Of course, we know housing, rents have gone up dramatically, food, of course, and also those energy bills. So we continue to be very concerned."
Goldie says even with tomorrow's boost, JobSeeker will still be
the lowest unemployement payment
among all of the OECD's 38 member countries.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A 24-year-old man has been charged with two counts of attempted murder over the stabbing of two female students at the Australian National University (ANU) in Canberra. Police allege the man hit another man on the head with a frying pan about 2:40pm on Monday at Fellows Oval. The man then allegedly stabbed a female student multiple times before chasing and stabbing a second female student. Police allege the man then approached a second male student and punched him in the face. The two 20-year-old female students were taken to hospital, where one remains in a serious but stable condition, and the other in a stable condition. The two male victims did not need hospital treatment. The 24-year-old man was taken into custody and charged with attempted murder, two counts of assault and one count of possessing an object to be used to kill. Police said no motive for the incident had been identified and they did not believe the victims knew the accused. You can read more about this story below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Man charged with attempted murder over stabbing of two ANU female students

featuredLink.title: Man charged with attempted murder over stabbing of two female students at ANU

children.content: ACT police officers at Fellows Oval on the ANU campus.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senior business correspondent Peter Ryan has been reading the minutes from the Reserve Bank's meeting earlier this month when it kept the official cash rate on hold at 4.1 per cent. The minutes have just been released and here is Peter's report: The Reserve Bank has signalled that inflation remains a clear and present danger to the economy and that another interest rate rise can’t be ruled out. That’s despite evidence that twelve interest rate rises since May last year are continuing to slow the economy with RBA board members warning inflation is still too high. While the RBA board left the cash rate at hold at its meeting a fortnight ago, the minutes released this morning show the battle to get 4.9 percent inflation back into the 2 to 3 percent target zone is far from over. In considering whether the inflict another rate hike, the Board noted that inflation was “still too high” and “was expected to remain so for an extended period”. While headline inflation is slowing, the minutes show concern that services inflation might take a while to decline and that the labour market remains tight with the jobless rate hovering around a 50 year low. “Were inflation to remain above target for an even longer period, this could cause inflation expectations to move higher which would likely require an even larger increase,” the minutes warn. However, members also note that the economy is “experiencing a period of subdued growth” led by household consumption as high inflation and rate rises weigh on household budgets. As the impact of rate rises hit, the Board noted the risk “the economy could slow more sharply than forecast” - in other words a hard economic landing. The minutes show a deepening concern about China where conditions in the property market had deteriorated further. “Members noted .. significant challenges from financial stress among developers and further defaults posed a risk to economic activity.” Board members said they would be guided by incoming economic data in assessing the need for further hikes. Money markets only see an 8 percent probability of a cash rate rise to 4.35 percent at the RBA’s October meeting. However, if inflation makes a comeback or remains sticky, there is an outside chance of another rate rise before the end of the year. Judo Bank economic adviser Warren Hogan sees the outside chance of a November rate rise on Melbourne Cup Day as the final nail in the coffin of inflation. The minutes make no mention of Philip Lowe’s final meeting as Reserve Bank governor. Michele Bullock is in her second day as RBA governor and will chair the next meeting on October 3.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA says inflation remains a threat

children.content: Senior business correspondent Peter Ryan has been reading the minutes from the Reserve Bank's meeting earlier this month when it kept the official cash rate on hold at 4.1 per cent.
The minutes have just been released and here is Peter's report:
The Reserve Bank has signalled that inflation remains a clear and present danger to the economy and that another interest rate rise can’t be ruled out.
That’s despite evidence that twelve interest rate rises since May last year are continuing to slow the economy with RBA board members warning inflation is still too high.

While the RBA board left the cash rate at hold at its meeting a fortnight ago, the minutes released this morning show the battle to get 4.9 percent inflation back into the 2 to 3 percent target zone is far from over.
In considering whether the inflict another rate hike,
the Board noted that inflation was “still too high”
and “was expected to remain so for an extended period”.

While headline inflation is slowing, the minutes show concern that services inflation might take a while to decline and that the labour market remains tight with the jobless rate hovering around a 50 year low.
“Were inflation to remain above target for an even longer period, this could cause inflation expectations to move higher which would likely require an even larger increase,” the minutes warn.
However, members also note that
the economy is “experiencing a period of subdued growth”
led by household consumption as high inflation and rate rises weigh on household budgets.
As the impact of rate rises hit, the Board noted the risk “the economy could slow more sharply than forecast” - in other words a hard economic landing.
The minutes show a deepening concern about China where conditions in the property market had deteriorated further.
“Members noted .. significant challenges from financial stress among developers and further defaults posed a risk to economic activity.”
Board members said they would be guided by incoming economic data in assessing the need for further hikes.
Money markets only see an 8 percent probability of a cash rate rise to 4.35 percent at the RBA’s October meeting.
However, if inflation makes a comeback or remains sticky, there is an outside chance of another rate rise before the end of the year.
Judo Bank economic adviser Warren Hogan sees the outside chance of a November rate rise on Melbourne Cup Day as the final nail in the coffin of inflation.
The minutes make no mention of Philip Lowe’s final meeting as Reserve Bank governor.
Michele Bullock is in her second day as RBA governor and will chair the next meeting on October 3.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Retail workers were seen as heroes during the COVID-19 shutdowns, however assaults and aggression against shop staff are on the rise according to the Australian Retail Association. It's calling for tougher penalties in Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and ACT for people who assault retail employees. A survey by the Association found that 91 per cent of retailers have experienced retail crime, including shoplifting and customer aggression. Nearly 50 per cent have seen an increase in organised crime. The Association's chief executive Paul Zahra says the surge in retail crime is making it harder to find staff. “All retail workers, whether they’re a casual in their first job or doing the night shift at the local  convenience store, have a right to feel safe at work," Mr Zahra says. “It shouldn’t be the norm to be spat at, yelled at or punched for simply doing your job." I spoke to Mr Zahra on the ABC News Channel.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Retailers call for tougher penalties for shopworker assaults

children.content: Retail workers
were seen as heroes during the
COVID-19
shutdowns, however assaults and aggression against shop staff are on the rise according to the
Australian Retail Association.
It's calling for tougher penalties in Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and ACT for people who assault retail employees.
A survey by the Association found that
91 per cent of retailers
have experienced retail crime, including shoplifting and customer aggression.
Nearly 50 per cent have seen an increase in organised crime.
The Association's chief executive Paul Zahra
says the surge in retail crime is making it harder to find staff.
“All retail workers, whether they’re a casual in their first job or doing the night shift at the local  convenience store, have a right to feel safe at work," Mr Zahra says.
“It shouldn’t be the norm to be spat at, yelled at or punched for simply doing your job."
I spoke to Mr
Zahra
on the ABC News Channel.

props.synopsis: It's barely detectable to the human eye, but a microscopic parasite has decimated wombat populations across south-east Australia. title.children: Wombats are solitary creatures. So how is a deadly mite that's wiping out populations being transmitted?

props.synopsis: In waters around Australia's coastline are about 1 million tonnes of pipelines, moorings, fixed rigs and floating vessels. Many are due for "decommissioning" and operators are contractually obliged to remediate the sites. But the cost is gargantuan, and not everyone wants to pay, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: Our waters are awash with ageing gas and oil infrastructure. What happens when these behemoths are no longer needed?
